thread.title: Unusual Easter Traditions in Germany

title: Unusual Easter Traditions in Germany
text:
By Erin Porter Updated March 21, 2016 . 
Easter in Germany is a special time. For the religious, this is a time of reflection and family with well-attended Sunday services. For the children, Easter eggs - Osterei - will be decorated and much chocolate consumed. 
And for everyone else? Easter means a long weekend as Good Friday and Easter Monday are public holidays. German school holidays are usually around this time (about two weeks) meaning many people in Germany take this time to travel. While stores, government offices and banks are closed, hotels, museums, trains and roads will be extra crowded. 
However you choose to celebrate this holiday, Germany is ready to exult in spring . Flowers are in bloom and people are on vacation. 
If you prefer to eschew bunny rabbits for something a bit more interesting, Germany still has you covered. Trees covered in eggs? An Easter bonfire? A museum dedicated to the egg? Check, check and check. Here are four unusual Easter traditions and places in Germany. GNTB/Hans R. Colorvision Utthof 1. Easter tree 
Germans take decorating their eggs seriously (as they do so many things). Proper Osterei are hand-blown and carefully decorated with waxes and paints. Colorful eggs are also available for purchase at many grocery stores, with durable plastic eggs also available for display. Traditionally, the eggs should be bedecked in their Easter finest on Good Friday. And while some eggs may be hidden by the Osterhase ( Easter bunny), most German families put their Easter eggs on display in an Ostereierbaum (Easter egg tree). Not everyone has room for a full-fledged tree, so there are small decorative trees or you can hang the light-weight eggs from a vase of pussy willows. 
Saalfelder Ostereierbaum 
The most impressive example of an Ostereierbaum is a tree in Saalfeld, eastern Germany adorned with more than 9,000 Easter eggs! A simple apple tree in the garden of Volker Kraft has become a legit Easter attraction. The Kraft family has been decorating the tree since 1965 and the small personal celebration had grown to thousands of eggs by 2012. Curious visitors can peruse the tree for free and it is estimated that about 8,000 people come to gaze in wonder each year. 
However, this is actually not the record-holding Ostereierbaum . Rostock 's Zoo holds that distinction for hanging 79,596 blown and painted eggs from a red oak in April 2007. 
continue reading below our video Beware! The 5 Most Common Travel Scams Photo: Passionsspiele Oberammergau 2000 2. Passion Play in Oberammergau 
If you prefer your Easter celebrations a little more Christian-centric, Oberammergau is famous for its Passion Play . The depiction of Christ’s trial and death is re-enacted by the residents of this Bavarian village to thank God for sparing them from the plague in 1633. 
The six hour epic play is performed every ten years for a seven days-a-week run from May to October. If you want to see some village people perform, you will have to wait until the next performance in 2020. More » 3. Easter Bonfire 
Wondering what to do with those pussy willows from your home-made Ostereierbaum ? Add it to the Easter bonfire on Sunday. This cleansing fire is part of a pagan ritual made to welcome the spring. Today's fires happen around every major city - just watch for the light and join the crowds around the flames. More » Ariel Skelley/Getty Images 4. Ostereimuseum 
The only Ostereimuseum (Easter Egg Museum) in Germany is a tiny temple to the most important symbol of Easter. Located near Stuttgart in Sonnenbühl, this unusual 2-story museum covers all things egg. For over 20 years this site has showcased egg holders, Osterei as a work of art and different animals eggs decorated in the holiday style.
